title: Ticket #3209: Add support for spot instances to EC2 GAHP
description:
Tony Tiradani writes: 

  > I have recently received requests from both CMS and HCC to provide EC2
  > Spot Instance support in glideinWMS since spot instances are
  > significantly cheaper than ordinary instances.  In order to do this, we
  > need Condor to support EC2 Spot Instances.


  > Could we have the following API calls added to the support list?


  > These calls are required to get spot instance to work:


  > RequestSpotInstances
  > CancelSpotInstanceRequests
  > DescribeSpotInstanceRequests


  > This one would be a second order request.  I envision using it to provide
  > matching capabilities per availability zone.


  > DescribeSpotPriceHistory
remarks:
2012-Aug-24 16:25:18 by tstclair:
Really...? wow, you would want DMTCP or something to ensure job recovery.

2012-Aug-24 16:29:09 by tlmiller:
I've added the following commands to the EC2 GAHP: 

  EC2_VM_START_SPOT
  EC2_VM_STATUS_SPOT
  EC2_VM_STOP_SPOT
  EC2_VM_STATUS_ALL_SPOT

all equivalent to the commands without the _SPOT suffix, and corresponding to the RequestSpotInstances, DescribeSpotInstanceRequests, CancelSpotInstanceRequests API commands, respectively. (EC2_VM_STATUS_ALL_SPOT issues an unfiltered DescribeSpotInstanceRequests command.)

After discussion with Jaime, I've decided to extend to EC2Job class's state machine with five new states: GM_START_SPOT, GM_SPOT_SUBMITTED, GM_PROBE_SPOT, GM_CANCEL_SPOT, and GM_CHECK_FOR_SPOT (used during recovery). To summarize, we're going to change the rest of the state machine as little as possible, and instead jump into a subgraph that deals with spot instances. We can do this by forbidding persistent spot requests and spot requests which can spawn more than one instance; if requested by our users, we can emulate/implement those features in Condor proper. (Effectively, once we've cancelled the spot request and removed its information (and added the instance ID), the job is a normal instance job, and can be treated as such.)

2012-Nov-14 13:48:37 by jfrey:
CODE REVIEW

  • General note: try to match the tab/space style of surrounding code.

  • In GM_PROBE_JOB, EC2Job::errorString shouldn't have newlines.

  • In GM_CLEAR_REQUEST, you should be setting ATTR_EC2_SPOT_REQUEST_ID to Undefined. You need to do this before the check for dirty attributes and in such a way that subsequent calls into doEvaluateState() don't re-dirty the attribute. One way to do this is to check whether m_spot_request_id is empty. If it isn't, set to the empty string and set the attribute to Undefined in the job ad.

  • In GM_SPOT_CANCEL, when you clear m_spot_request_id, you could also set ATTR_EC2_SPOT_REQUEST_ID to Undefined in the job ad and call requestScheddUpdate(this, false). That would avoid an unnecessary EC2 command on any subsequent failure recovery.

  • In GM_SPOT_START, you switch to GM_SPOT_CANCEL if the job is held or removed. Nothing will happen in GM_SPOT_CANCEL, as we don't have a spot instance request id. Also, if we have an ec2_spot_start command in progress, we have to wait for the result before leaving this state. Otherwise, we can leak a spot instance request.

  • In GM_SPOT_QUERY, the comments say that ec2_spot_status() should return 0 or 1 spot instance request, and in the case of 1, it'll be the one we're interested in. The code handles getting multiple requests, but assumes our request is one of them. The code could be improved to handle receiving results that don't include our own request.

  • In GM_SPOT_QUERY, you switch to GM_DONE_SAVE if the spot instance request's status isn't "active" or "open". Shouldn't it be putting the job on hold, and possibly canceling the request first?
